vii [ras pgiigi or   eaeznvs

Study an embryo in which the blastoderm has spread over the
entire yolk. Certain prominences or irregularities on the surface
of the egg are appearing (5 to 5 days) as follows: (figures in
MacBride}.
l. Cn Use animal pole the shell gland with a depression in its
center.
2. Lateral prominences.
5. Between the and the mantle on each side there is an imcon-
spicuous ridge which will develop into part of the siphon. They
are called the lateral siphon folds. Turn the embryo over to see
them clearly. lf` A ll
4. The arms are appearing as paired protrusions. How many at
first? All these will become more prominent as development proceeds.
Draw.
VII. EMERQOS FIYE TO TEN DAYS QLD
ll. Place embryos of various stages in a watch glass and compare
them noting the further development of the organs mentioned above an; 
also the appearance of new organs. A careful comparison of older
and younger embryos will enable you to recognize most of the organs
and in this way you can trace them back to their beginnings. lt will
be desirable to tear off the jelly envelopes with needles or punc~
ture them. `Use figs. in Brooks, Korschelt and Naef.
For purposes of cdnparison call the mantle dorsal and the yolk
end ventral. The siphon side is posterior. Study mostly posterior
aspects although profile views should be consulted frequently. A
frequent turning of die embryo will be advantageous for a better
orientation of parts:~
Recognize the most obvious things first.
l. Note that the yolk mass gradually constriets in the neighbor-
hood of the embryo and remains as a very prominent oval mass for
a long time. lt may be seen also as a dark plug within the embryo,
extending as a point into the mantle area and also similarly into
the stalks. What finally becomes of the yolk mass?
2. Note the development of the mantle until it fits like a
hat over the dorsal end of the embryo, ls there a mantle chamber
beneath the mantle in any of the embryos? 
5. Note that the <2 es become prominent. Do they resemble the
eyes of vertebrates? Iens present? Optic cup?
4. The otoeysts appear early as a pair of spherical sacs. Do
any of them dnntain otolithsi They move closer together as develop-
ment proceeds.
5. Dorsal to the and beneath the mantle there is a pair
of gills. They are not very prominent at first but become so later,
